Detect Outliers Using Isolation Forest

Source: R/detect_outliers.R
detect_outliers.Rd

Main function to detect outliers in tabular data using isotree with automatic parameter tuning and comprehensive diagnostics.

Usage

detect_outliers(
  data,
  target_cols = NULL,
  contamination = 0.1,
  tune = TRUE,
  tune_method = c("grid", "random", "bayesian"),
  n_trees = 100,
  sample_size = "auto",
  max_depth = "auto",
  seed = NULL,
  parallel = TRUE,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

data

A data.frame or data.table containing the data to analyze

target_cols

Character vector of column names to analyze. If NULL (default), all numeric columns are used

contamination

Numeric between 0 and 1. Expected proportion of outliers. Used for automatic threshold determination. Default: 0.1

tune

Logical. Should hyperparameters be tuned? Default: TRUE

tune_method

Character. Tuning method: "grid", "random", or "bayesian". Default: "grid"

n_trees

Integer. Number of trees in isolation forest. Default: 100

sample_size

Integer or "auto". Sample size for each tree. Default: "auto"

max_depth

Integer or "auto". Maximum tree depth. Default: "auto"

seed

Integer. Random seed for reproducibility. Default: NULL

parallel

Logical. Use parallel processing for tuning? Default: TRUE

verbose

Logical. Print progress messages? Default: TRUE

Value

An object of class "outlier_detector" containing:

model

The trained isotree model

scores

Anomaly scores for each observation

outliers

Logical vector indicating outlier status

outlier_details

data.table with detailed outlier information per row and column

threshold

The anomaly score threshold used

params

Model parameters used

metrics

Performance metrics

data

Original data (optionally stored)

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
library(outlieR)

# Basic usage
result <- detect_outliers(mtcars)

# With specific columns and custom contamination
result <- detect_outliers(
  data = iris,
  target_cols = c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width"),
  contamination = 0.05
)

# Without automatic tuning
result <- detect_outliers(
  data = mtcars,
  tune = FALSE,
  n_trees = 200,
  max_depth = 10
)
} # }
